resource.chars:
uncommon.

63  There may be some doubt in the first instance, as to the light
in which we are to regard the specimens represented in Plate
II Fig 8; whether as a 'monstrosity by excess', or as the product
of the <s>[?]</s> fusion of the two individuals; but I think<s>,</s> this will be
removed by a closer examination. For it is obvious that
the smaller disk which is surrounded by the outer zones
of the larger one, has been developed from a nucleus of its own;
and this nucleus does not appear to have any direct
connection with the periphery, still less with the centre
of the larger disk; and on the other hand, when we consider
the circumstances under which Orbitolites grow (§34), it is
very easy to understand that the smaller and younger
individual, having attached itself in too near proximity to the
larger and older one, should become imbedded therein
(so to speak) by the extension of the newly forming zones
pf the latter around its margin. In fact, the manner in
which the outer zones of the larger disk envelope the smaller,
precisely corresponds with that in which we have seen the
the new zones originating from the uninjured margin of a mutilated
specimen to extend<s>ing</s> themselves along its fractured edges (§37).
